title: In vitro thrombolytic activity of Dhamasa (Fagonia arabica Linn.), Kushta (Saussurea lappa Decne.), and Guduchi (Tinospora cordifolia Thunb.).
authorString: Chaudhary S, Godatwar PK, Sharma R.

affiliation: Lecturer, Department of Roga Nidana and Vikriti Vijnana, Aligarh Unani and Ayurvedic Medical College, Aligarh, UP, India.
Department of Roga Nidana and Vikriti Vigyan, National Institute of Ayurveda, Jaipur, Rajasthan, India.
Department of Roga Nidana and Vikriti Vigyan, National Institute of Ayurveda, Jaipur, Rajasthan, India.

abstractText: Thrombotic disorders are among the major fatal conditions affecting the society. Treatment modalities used for such disorders are either surgical interventions or use of drugs such as urokinase, streptokinase (SK), or tissue plasminogen activators to dissolve the blood clots. These modalities have their own limitations and side effects apart from being expensive. There is a need for safer and cost effective antithrombolytic agents.To evaluate in vitro thrombolytic property of Dhamasa (Fagonia arabica Linn.), Kushta (Saussurea lappa Decne.), and Guduchi (Tinospora cordifolia Thunb.) plant extract.Venous blood drawn from 20 healthy volunteers was allowed to form clots which was weighed and treated with the extract of test plant materials to disrupt the clots. Weight of clot after and before treatment provided a percentage of clot lysis. SK was used as a positive and water as a negative control.The significance between % clot lysis of five groups by means of weight difference was tested by the one-way ANOVA.Clot lysis observed were 68.06%, 14.85%, 25.01%, 92.54%, and 3.00% for Dhamasa, Kushta, Guduchi, SK, and distilled water, respectively.Herbal extracts possess thrombolytic properties and lyse blood clots in vitro.
affiliation: Lecturer, Department of Roga Nidana and Vikriti Vijnana, Aligarh Unani and Ayurvedic Medical College, Aligarh, UP, India.
